messages.content:
Take on the role of a Shards game developer coding expert who is tasked to teach/educate other game developers how to code using Shards. 
You are teaching Shards programming language in the context of game development. 
Your intended audience has knowledge of other programming languages but not Shards. 
They have to learn Shards for game development fast as they are entering a Shards coding competition very soon and need to quickly become Shards coding experts.
Hence, please ensure your answers are correct and clear.
Please resolve the query step by step to ensure your Shards code is correct.
Shards works in wires and meshes. Functional code runs in each wire, and many wires run on a particular mesh. 
Wires are defined like:
@wire(<respective-wirename>{
    the functional code 
})

Meshes are initialised like: 
{logic-behavior: <respective-wirename>}
{graphics-behavior: <respective-wirename>}
{ui-behavior: <respective-wirename>}
The code in the wires can only be executed when they are run on a mesh as defined above.


I need your help to understand and generate some commands in the form of Shards scripts to be sent to our game creation system (Formabble), which is Right Handed with Y as up axis, from whatever the user inputs.

### A bit about Shards:

String: "hello world"
Integer: 1
Float: 1.0
Float2: @f2(1.0 2.0)
Float3: @f3(1.1 2.0 3.0)
We also have @f4
Int vectors also: @i2, @i3, @i4, @i8 and @i16@ is a prefix for our built-ins, definitions and templates to distinguish between variables
; is the line comment symbol, ignore comments

Shards ["Hello " @name] | String.Join | Log >= message [] is a sequence, in the above you can see that @name is something defined, while message is a variable we assign with >= which is a mutable assignment operator, as you can see in Shards everything flows from left to right from top to bottom, even assignments.
> is used to update mutable values
= is used to assign am immutable reference

Shards Count(seq) When({IsMore(0) | And | IsMore(selected-idx)} {   ; DO SOMETHING With Count(seq) output }) 
In this Shards script, we start by counting the elements in seq. Then, we evaluate two conditions in sequence: first, we check if the count is greater than zero.
If this is true, we then check if the count is also greater than selected-idx. Both conditions must be satisfied for the script to execute the code within the block

Types are strict, so when you use or pass a constant 0 will be an integer 0.0 will be float
Same when declaring variables:
0.0 >= float-var0 >= int-var
Types are also strict when doing math! so please use right types, you can use ToFloat, ToInt etc to convert.
Variables must be unique! Don't Set with same name. Unless it's an Update (>)
Example, idx | Math.Mod(10), if you need float output use idx | Math.Mod(10) | ToFloat
If idx is a float you need to do: idx | ToInt | Math.Mod(10) | ToFloat
E.g.
idx | ToFloat | Math.Divide(5.0) | Math.Floor = row row | Math.Mod(2) | ToFloat | Math.Multiply(1.0) = zExtraOffset ; <------- WRONG, should be: row | ToInt| Math.Mod(2) | ToFloat | Math.Multiply(1.0) = zExtraOffset
Or
idx | Math.Mod(5) = column column | ToFloat | Math.Multiply(1.75) = zOffset ; column came from Mod output, so was a Int!

This part about the Math Shards is very important. Math is done like this in Shards:
time | Math.Multiply(0.2) | Math.AxisAngleX | Math.Rotation ; Rotation X | Math.MatMul((time | Math.Multiply(0.7) | Math.AxisAngleY | Math.Rotation)) ; Rotation Y | Math.MatMul((time | Math.Multiply(0.9) | Math.AxisAngleZ | Math.Rotation)) ; Rotation Z | Log+ is Math.Add, - is Math.Subtract, * is Math.Multiply, / is Math.Divide
Shards doesn't use conventional math operators such as (+,-,*,/) like most other programming langauges. Math operations in Shards are called via num1 Math.Add(num2), num1 Math.Subtract(num2), num1 Math.Multiply(num2), num1 Math.Multiply(num2) respectively.   
Math is always processed from left to right. 
so this is wrong @f3(1 + index1 2 1 + index2), but it can be achieved using () construct which will wrap the operation and create a temp variable such as:
@f3((1 | Math.Add(x)) 2 (1 | Math.Add(y)))
For Trigonometric functions, Math.Sin(30) and Math.Cos(3) etc. are wrong. The correct form is 30 Math.Sin and 30 Math.Cos respectively.
Also keep in mind that Math.Floor will output a float! so you might need to ToInt its output!!

Also Shards is sort of strongly typed so this would be wrong:
f3(0.0 (idx | Math.Multiply(1.0)) 0.0) 
The correct code is:
@f3(0.0 (idx | ToFloat | Math.Multiply(1.0)) 0.0)

Loops:
0 >= idx ; we need to manage manually the index Repeat({   Msg("Hello")   Math.Inc(idx) } Times: 3)
or
ForRange(0 2 {   = idx ; we get automatically the current index   Msg("Hello") })

Seq access and creation
1 >> s 2 >> s  s | Take(0) | Assert.Is(1)

Tables access and creation
{a: 1 b: 2} = t ; actually any JSON will do, our tables are like json tables  t | Take("a") | Assert.Is(1)
Always prefer declaring tables in JSON style though! and Immutable.

Random numbers!
RandomFloat(Max: 1.0) | IsLess(1.0) | Assert.Is(true) RandomInt(Max: 100) | IsLess(100) | Assert.Is(true)

Remember:
this is wrong:
@f3(randomX 0.0 y | Math.Multiply(10.0)) = position
it should be:
@f3(randomX 0.0 (y | Math.Multiply(10.0))) = position as you need () for such lambda behavior

Some Formabble specific functionality:
* Formalize
* Description
* Spawn or create an entity (a form in our case) from a form asset in the environment or scene (called domain in our case).
* Example
* {Graphics: {"fbl/pose": {translation: @f3(0.0 0.0 0.0) rotation: @f4(0.0 0.0 0.0 1.0) scale: @f3(1.0 1.0 1.0)}}} | Fbl.Formalize("__ASSET_ID__")
* Notes
* Important: Always include all TRS components, even if default!!
* Important: Rotation is always a quaternion
* Dispatch
* Description
* Dispatches a variable change to the requested form in the right subsystem
* Examples
* Math.Decompose = gizmo-trs | gizmo-trs | Take("translation") | Fbl.Dispatch(form-id WirePoolType::Graphics "fbl/pose" Key: "translation") (Key is optional)
* 10.0 | Fbl.Dispatch("cube1" WirePoolType::Graphics "speed")

Now from now on you will wait for user prompts and generate commands.
For now just focus on Formalizing forms. User input will be natural language instructions.
Please output a Shard script with all the code to achieve the requested instructions.
Be brief, omit validation for now.
Oh and please from now on just answer queries related to Formabble and Shards.

Examples:
A RANDOM FOREST
0 >= idx ForRange(0 99 {   idx | ToFloat | Math.Divide(10.0) | Math.Floor = x   idx | Math.Mod(10) = z   RandomFloat(Max: 1.0) | Math.Multiply(10.0) = randomX   RandomFloat(Max: 1.0) | Math.Multiply(10.0) = randomZ   @f3((x | Math.Add(randomX)) 0.0 (z | ToFloat | Math.Add(randomZ))) = position   {Graphics: {"fbl/pose": {translation: position rotation: @f4(0.0 0.0 0.0 1.0) scale: @f3(1.0)}}} | Fbl.Formalize("d-treeDefault")   Math.Inc(idx) })

A GRID OF BLOCKS
0 >= idx ForRange(0 99 {   idx | ToFloat | Math.Divide(10.0) | Math.Floor = x   idx | Math.Mod(10) | ToFloat = z   @f3(x 0.0 z) = position   {Graphics: {"fbl/pose": {translation: position rotation: @f4(0.0 0.0 0.0 1.0) scale: @f3(1.0)}}} | Fbl.Formalize("d-block")   Math.Inc(idx) })

ALWAYS PREFER SIMPLE CODE, DON'T NEED TO OPTIMIZE, UNROLL OPERATIONS ETC!
Your reply should look like this:
MARKDOWN SHARDS CODE BLOCK TO EVAL
LINE BREAK
COMMENTS
How do I check more than one condition?
placeholder-system-prompt
How to add a new element to the end of an existing Shards sequence?

element | 
    AppendTo(sequence) Get(element) | 
    AppendTo(Collection: sequence)
    The AppendTo Shard adds an element that is passed as input to the end of a sequence specified in the Collection parameter.
    This Shard works on both string and sequence variables.
    The type  of element being appended needs to be of the same type as the sequence.
    #General
placeholder-system-prompt
How do I replace an element of an existing sequence?

[index0 variable1 index1 variable2] | Assoc(sequence)[index0 variable1 index1 variable2] 
    | Assoc(
      Name: sequence
      ;;Key: key
    )
    The Assoc Shard is replacing element of index 0 in sequence with variable1 and element with index of 1 in sequence to variable2.
    The input sequence for Assoc must always contain an even number of elements. 
    The elements of the input sequence are parsed in pairs. 
    The 1st element of each pair gives the index of the target element to update, and the 2nd element of that pair gives the new value for the target element.
    Assoc can also be used to update a specific key in a table.
    #General
placeholder-system-prompt
How do I convert bytes to String?

bytes
   BytesToString
  
    bytes
    BytesToString
  
    BytesToString is a Shard that takes in an input of type Bytes and converts it to type String.
    #General
placeholder-system-prompt
How do i delete all the elements in a sequence.

Clear(sequence)Clear(Name: sequence)
    Clear removes all the elements of the sequence that has been passed to it in the Name: parameter.
    This Shard works on both sequences and tables. 
    Use the Key: parameter to delete all elements of the specified key in a table.
    #General
placeholder-system-prompt
How do I create an unassigned constant in Shards.

Const(5) ;;Change the value accordinglyConst(Value: 5) ;;Change the value accordingly
    Const declares a constant value (of any data type) by passing it into the Value parameter.
    A constant value declared with Const is un-named i.e., it is not assigned to any variable or allocated any alias.
    In this scenario a constant value of  5 is declared and can be used as an input for other Shards.
    #General
placeholder-system-prompt
How do I get the total number of elements in a sequence?

Count(sequence-to-count)
  
    Count(
      Name: sequence-to-Count
      ;; Key: key
      )
  
    Count parses the variable passed to it in the Name parameter, and returns the count of characters, elements, or key-value pairs depending on 
    whether the data type passed to it was a string, a sequence, or a table. Parameter Key applies only to tables.
    #General
placeholder-system-prompt
How do I count the total number of key and value pairs that a table has ?

Count(table-to-count)
  
    Count
    (
      Name: table-to-count
      ;;Key: key-to-count
    )
  
    Count parses the value passed to it in the :Name parameter, and returns the count of characters, elements, or key-value pairs depending on whether the data type passed to it was a string, a sequence, or a table.
    This Shard works on both sequences and tables. Parameter :Key applies only to tables.
    #General
placeholder-system-prompt
How do I count the total number of elements  in a sequence of a key from a table

Count(table-to-count key-to-count)
  
    Count(Name: table-to-count Key: key-to-count)
  
    Count parses the value passed to it in the :Name parameter, and returns the count of characters, elements, or key-value pairs depending on whether the data type passed to it was a string, a sequence, or a table.
    This Shard works on both sequences and tables. Parameter :Key applies only to tables.
    #General

How do I remove the first element in the sequence and return the remaining sequence?

DropFront(sequence-to-drop)
   Log("Remaining Sequence")
  
    DropFront(Name: sequence-to-drop)
    Log(Prefix: "Remaining Sequence")
  
    DropFront removes the first element of the sequence variable that has been passed to in the Name parameter. Unlike the PopFront Shard, DropFront will return the remaining
    sequence as output.
    #General
placeholder-system-prompt
How do I remove the last element in the sequence and return the remaining sequence?

Drop(sequence-to-drop)
   Log("Remaining Sequence")
  
    Drop(Name: sequence-to-drop)
    Log(Prefix: "Remaining Sequence")
  
    Drop removes the last element of the sequence variable that has been passed to in the :Name parameter. Unlike the Pop Shard which will return 
    the popped element, Drop will return the remaining sequence as output.
    #General
placeholder-system-prompt
How do I delete an element in a sequence.

Erase([index-to-delete] sequence-to-delete-from)
  
    Erase(Indices:[index-to-delete] Name:sequence-to-delete-from)
  
    Erase deletes single or multiple elements (from sequences) and key-value pairs (from tables).
    For a sequence, this Shard expects the index (or a sequence of indices in descending order) of the element(s) to be erased, followed by the 
    name of the sequence variable in the Name parameter.
    #General
placeholder-system-prompt
How do I delete multiple elements in a sequence.

Erase([index-to-delete1 index-to-delete2 index-to-delete3] sequence-to-delete-from)
  
    Erase(Indices:[index-to-delete1 index-to-delete2 index-to-delete3] Name:sequence-to-delete-from)
  
    Erase deletes single or multiple elements (from sequences) and key-value pairs (from tables).
    For a sequence, this Shard expects the index (or a sequence of indices in descending order) of the element(s) to be erased, followed by the name of the sequence variable in the Name parameter.
    To delete more elements, add the more Indeces to the sequence in the Indeces parameter.
    #General
placeholder-system-prompt
How do I delete keys from a table

Erase(["key1" "key2"] sequence-to-delete-from)
  
    Erase(Indices:["key1" "key2"] Name:sequence-to-delete-from)
  
    Erase deletes single or multiple elements (from sequences) and key-value pairs (from tables).
    For a sequence, this Shard expects the index (or a sequence of indices in descending order) of the element(s) to be erased, followed by the name of the sequence variable in the Name parameter.
    To delete more keys, add the more keys to the sequence in the Keys parameter.
    #General
placeholder-system-prompt
How do I exit the program through code?

0;; Error Code
   Exit
  
    0;; Error Code
    Exit
  
    Exit is a Shard that will automatically close the program. It takes in a integer as input. 
    This integer is usually to denote the error code.
    If there is no error code to be used as input use 0.
    #General
placeholder-system-prompt
How do I ensure that the output of a Shard is a specific type?

output-to-check ;; use any of the Shards below to check the required type
   Expect(@type (Type::None))
   Expect(@type(Type::Any))
   Expect(@type(Type::Bool))
   Expect(@type(Type::Int))
   Expect(@type(Type::Int2))
   Expect(@type(Type::Int3))
   Expect(@type(Type::Int4))
   Expect(@type(Type::Int8))
   Expect(@type(Type::Int16))
   Expect(@type(Type::Float))
   Expect(@type(Type::Float2))
   Expect(@type(Type::Float3))
   Expect(@type(Type::Float4))
   Expect(@type(Type::Color))
   Expect(@type(Type::Wire))
   Expect(@type(Type::Shard))
   Expect(@type(Type::Bytes))
   Expect(@type(Type::String))
   Expect(@type(Type::Image))
   Expect(@type(Type::Audio))
  
   output-to-check ;; use any of the Shards below to check the required type
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::None))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Any))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Bool))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Int))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Int2))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Int3))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Int4))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Int8))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Int16))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Float))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Float2))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Float3))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Float4))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Color))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Wire))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Shard))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Bytes))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::String))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Image))
   Expect(Type:@type(Type::Audio))
  
    The expect Shard will take an input and check if it is the stipulated type in the Type  parameter.If it is, it will return the input as the stipulated type.
    Otherwise, the program will fail.
    #General

How do I do something cumalatively for a specififed range.

0 >= forRange-each-cycle-value
    
    ForRange
    (
      1
      5
      {
        = added-value

        forRange-each-cycle-value
        Math.Add(added-value)
        > forRange-each-cycle-value

        Log("added-value")
      }
    )
  
   0 >= forRange-each-cycle-value
    
    ForRange
    (
      From:1
      To:5
      Action:{
        = added-value

        forRange-each-cycle-value
        Math.Add(added-value)
        > forRange-each-cycle-value

        Log("added-value")
      }
    )
  
    The ForRange Shard iterates over a range of numbers, feeding each number into the Action parameter and executes the process stated in the Action parameter.
    #General

bytes

How do I read the value of a variable.

"value" = variable

    Get(variable)
    Log("Variable read")"value" = variable

    Get(Name: variable)
    Log(Prefix: "Variable read")
    Get is used to read the value of an existing variable. All variables that can be created by Set, can be read by Get.
    #General

How do I read a value of a key from a table.

{k1: 1 k2: 2 k3: 3} = table

    Get(table k1 0)
    Log("Key read")None
    Get can be used to read the value of a Key from a table. While the Take Shard can also be used, there is a difference between the two. The difference being, if Get
    is trying to read a key that does not exist and no default value is provided, it will throw and error. Take on the otherhand will return none. Unlike Take, Get
    can also place a default value through its Default parameter for a key that does not exist yet.
    #General

How do I get the highest value from a sequence

[1 2 3 4 5] = seq
    Highest
    Log("resulting")[1 2 3 4 5] = seq
    Highest
    Log(Prefix:"resulting")
    The Highest shard will parse a sequence and return the element with the highest "value". If it is a sequence of integers or floats it will return the element with
    the highest integer or float. If it is a sequence of strings it will return the element with the highest value based on the lexicographical order.
    #General

How do I find the index number of a specific element in a sequence?

sequence
   |IndexOf(item-to-find)
   > index-of-item
  
   Get(Name:sequence)
   IndexOf(Item: item-to-find)
   Update(Name: index-of-item)
  
    Index of will take a sequence as an input and search through the sequence until it finds an exact match of the item stated in the Item parameter. Once a match
    has been found, it will return the index of the matched item.
    #General

How do I check if something is Almost a certain value

0 >= value

   value | Math.Add(1) > value

   value
   If(IsAlmost(10 1) {Msg("almost  10!")} {Msg("not there yet!")})
  
   0 >= value

   value | Math.Add(1) > value

   Get(value)
   If(Predicate: IsAlmost(Value: 10 Treshold:1) Then:{
    Msg("all matches")
    } Else: {
      Msg("not all matches")}
   )
  
    The IsAlmost Shard is a Shard that can be used in the Predicate parameter of conditional Shards like If and When.
    It will check if the input is near to the value stated in the Value parameter besed on the Treshold parameter. If the input
    value is nearing the value provided in the Value parameter, the Shard will return true, otherwise, it will return false.
    The input can be of any number type or a sequence of such types. If the Shard is comparing between two numeric sequences, it will compare the elements
    of the input sequence with the corresponding indexed element in the sequence provided into the the Value parameter.
    #General

IsRunning(wire-to-check)
   Log("Is wire running")

    Log(Prefix: "Is wire running")
  
    The IsRunning shard will check if the wire stated in the Wire parameter is running. If it is running, it will return true, and false otherwise. In the solution

How do process a sequence but process only some parts of a sequence.

[1 2 3 4 5] = sequence 

   sequence
   Limit(3)
   | ForEach({
    Math.Add(1)
   })
  
   [1 2 3 4 5] = sequence 

   sequence
   Limit(Max:3)
   | ForEach(Apply:{
    Math.Add(1)
   })
  
    The Limit Shard takes a sequence as an input and outputs a cut sequence whose length is what is stated in the Max parameter. In the scenario provided under solution,
    the Limit Shard will output [1 2 3] and the ForEach Shard will only process these 3 elements.
    #General

How do i change all the low values in a sequence to another value.

[1 2 3 4 5] >= sequence

    sequence
    Max(Operand: 3) ;; change the operand accordingly to the desirec value
    > sequence
    Log("resulting sequence")
    ;; [3 3 3 4 5]
    [1 2 3 4 5] >= sequence

    sequence
    Max(Operand: 3) ;; change the operand accordingly to the desirec value
    > sequence
    Log("resulting sequence")
    ;; [3 3 3 4 5]
    
    This Shard compares the input to its Operand parameter and outputs the greater of the two values.

    If the input is a sequence and the Operand parameter a single number, each input element is compared with the Operand parameter and the greater value from each comparison is collected and output as a sequence.

    If the input and Operand parameter both are sequences, each element of the input sequence is compared with the corresponding-index element in the Operand parameter sequence and the greater value from each comparison is collected and output as a sequence.

    If the input sequence is smaller in size than the Operand parameter sequence the comparison stops with the last element of the input sequence.
